chapterTitle: Net Present Value and Other Investment Criteria

columns.text: $a)$ An internal rate of return seems to be the discount rate which makes the net present value of a sequence of cash flows equal to zero. As a reason, the internal rate of return can be understood as a financial break-even rate of return; at the internal rate of return, the project's net value is zero. Accept projects with an internal rate of returns larger than just the discount rate, but reject projects have an internal rate of returns worse than the discount rate, according to an internal rate of return decision rule.

$b)$ As much as when the project's cash flows remain conventional and also the project is independent, the estimates of both the internal required return and net present value approaches are compatible, according to traditional cash flows, the first cash flow is negative while the remainder is positive, a self-contained project is one in which the decision to accept or decline one project has no bearing on the decision to accept or decline any other projects.

In some circumstances, the net present value method is preferable to the internal rate of return method, while there are unusual financial flows and mutually exclusive investment initiatives, several problems can occur, in certain cases, the internal rate of return method's outcome will not provide a reliable decision on whether to approve or decline a project.

$c)$ Even though financial analysts preferred to communicate with rates of return rather than monetary values, financial managers utilize the internal rate of return method in conjunction with net present value, internal rate of return seems to be a very simple and rapid method of sharing project information.

If there is no discount rate available in the market, internal rate of return is a better statistic to employ than the net present value, throughout this scenario, choosing a rate to discount cash flows under net present value is quite challenging, without knowing the suitable discount rate, internal rate of return can be approximated and is recommended above net present value in this case.
